Award.AwardTitle: Physical and Photophysical Properties of Spin-Polarized Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration: This research award in the Inorganic, Bioinorganic, and Organometallic Chemistry program supports work by Professor James K. McCusker at Michigan State University to study the effect of spin and spin polarization on the physical and photophysical properties of molecules. Specifically, the research focuses on the design and development of chemical systems that will probe whether there exists a cause-and-effect relationship between the physical/photophysical properties of molecules and their innate spin properties, and if so, to what extent can that connection be exploited in order to manipulate the chemical reactivity of molecules. These efforts involve the application of various spectroscopic measurements (both steady-state and time-resolved) that will establish on a fundamental level the thermodynamic and kinetic influence of zero-field spin polarization on the ground- and excited-state properties of molecules. Additionally, the program will explore the connection between spin polarization and chemical reactivity through a series of experiments that will probe spin effects on energy transfer, electron transport through single spin-coupled molecules, as well as polarization transfer through a molecular bridge. The nature of the research is interdisciplinary; students involved in this project (undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students) will receive broad-based training in synthetic chemistry, state-of-the-art spectroscopic methodology, magnetism, and theory while at the same time working on projects having relevance to fields as diverse as molecular electronics, magnetism, photochemistry, and catalysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research program that has been supported through this grant from the National Science Foundation has dealt with a very fundamental aspect of the properties of molecules, but has yielded results that have the potential to significantly impact areas of science well beyond the subdiscipline of chemistry from which it originated. In the most general terms, our research has been concerned with the spin of electrons. Electron spin is a fundamental property of Nature. The distinctive color of gold, for example, is generally regarded as having its origins in relativistic effects, which in turn links electron spin to the unique optical characteristics of this element and likely constitutes a person’s first (unwitting) exposure to this phenomenon. The magnetic properties of materials derive mainly from the magnetic dipole created by the spin angular momentum of the electron, thus making magnetism another common source for widely held perceptions of electron spin and its consequences. The emerging fields of spintronics and quantum computing seek to utilize spin as a means for retaining and/or transmitting large amounts of information and offer nearly unlimited possibilities in terms of data storage and the virtually instantaneous transmission of information. In all of these cases, an implicit connection between spin and its phenomenological effects lie at the heart of a range of physical properties manifest at both the microscopic and macroscopic level. What is lacking from this palate of information is a connection between spin and the chemistry of molecules.

   We have pursued the design and development of chemical systems that are allowing us to determine whether there exists a cause-and-effect relationship between the physical and light-induced behavior of molecules and their innate spin properties, and if so, to what extent can we exploit this connection in order to manipulate the chemical reactivity of molecular systems. Although research is never "finished", the support from NSF for this basic research has resulted in a number of exciting discoveries. For example, conservation of angular momentum is an example of another fundamental property of nature. It is manifest in settings as foreign as black holes in space to ones as familiar as the image of a figure skater spinning faster and faster as he/she draws their arms into their body. The research supported through this grant has allowed us to demonstrate for the first time that this same prinicple applies to the process of transferring energy from one part of a molecule to another. Thus, the same concept that allows astrophysicists to infer the presence of satellites around a distant planet can now be used to design a chemical reaction. Other work arising from our efforts have included the development of ways in which the magnetic properties of molecules can be tailored through chemical synthesis, as well as an understanding of how molecules convert absorbed energy in chemical energy on time scales faster than a millionth of a millionth of a second.

   Perhaps more important than the discoveries that were made through this research is the intellectual capital that was generated through education. When a student enters graduate school and embarks on a research project, he/she has for the duration of their academic career been focused on absorbing knowledge. As scientists, our job is the creation of new knowledge; the research supported by this grant provides the mechanism through which that transformation can occur.
